pages.text: Foci are the source of power in $(l:world/rites_intro)$(marked)Rites$(). They are as essential to them as anything else; however, they are sometimes also a bit trickier to handle.$(br2)First of all, one must understand what a Focus in the World is:$(br)In the World, Foci are commonly material objects, like a unnatural sword or $(marked)Candles$().

Both are Foci; however, they are used in different manners. This is why Foci are classified as either $(l)Held$() Foci or $(l)Placed$() Foci. In the example of the sword and the Candles, the sword is a Held Focus, meaning that a caster must hold it in order to contribute to a Rite. The Candles however are Placed Foci; they may be placed close to the Rite in order to achieve the intended effect. This is the only way in which Foci practically differ.

When used, a Focus will, as mentioned before, contribute $(marked)Focal Power$() to a Rite. Additionally, each Focus will add $(marked)Instability$(), which is relevant when trying to avoid side effects.$(br)The amount of Focal Power and the amount of Instability added varies with each Focus.$(br)In addition to that, each type of Focus has a limit to how much it may be used.

Once this limit is reached, all Foci will contribute less Focal Power and more Instability; as example, using four skulls of the same type in a Rite already exceeds the limit of that Focus. This could be avoided by using different skulls.$(br)For the new Entheator, it is generally hard to know what things even have properties of Foci, and how strong they are if they do; however, this book provides help in such cases.

First of all, while there are still plenty of Foci to discover, this book contains a list of various $(o)known$() Foci. This list may be found on the last few pages of this entry.$(br2)Additionally, we wrote a guide to identify Foci, and vaguely determine their Focal Power, Instability and Usage Limit.$(br2)In order to take advantage of this, simply $(t:Do this by hovering over the item while pressing Shift)$(marked)inspect$() Held Foci in your inventory while holding this book.$()

In order to inspect Placed Foci, the Focus in question must be placed and $(t:Hold the book while pressing shift)inspected with this book$().$(br2)Still, the information given is extremely vague, so each Entheator must in the end develop some sort of feeling for Focal Power et cetera. Additionally, the information given does not respect any interactions possible, like the one seen in Statues.

pages.title: List of Known Foci
pages.text: $(li)$(l)Candles$()$(br)Candles will provide low amounts of Focal Power; however, they can be stacked, and that without increasing instability or counting to the usage limit.$(li)$(l)Skulls$()$(br)Skulls will provide greater amount of Focal Power, though the amount will vary depending on the skull used. Each skull type is a different Focus.

$(li)$(l)Gems$()$(br)Gems count as the same type of Focus; $(marked)Oceanic Gold$() however does not.$(li)$(l)Cultist Weapons$()$(br)Special Daggers worn by Cultist have the same inherent power; they all count as the same type of Focus.$(li)$(l)Artifacts$()$(br)Artifacts like the Star of Hell are immensely strong Foci; however, they usually have extremely low usage limits.

$(li)$(l)Altars$()$(br)Altars all count as the same type of Focus; they will provide greater amounts of power and usually form the base of Rites.$(li)$(l)Enchanted Items$()$(br)Any enchanted item may be used as Held Focus; this stacks with inherent Focal Properties. All enchanted items are considered the same type of focus.

$(li)$(l)Statues$()$(br)Statues are extremely powerful Foci when correctly used. A Statue is always dedicated to a Great Old One, and will yield the greatest effects when used together with a matching Octagram, golden Statues will even cancel most negative effects of Overloading; however, using a statue that addresses a different Great Old One might be a mistake. All Statues count as the same type of Focus.
